post_text: Frequent handwashing is an easy way to help keep our school communities safe. Parents are encouraged to discuss proper handwashing techniques with their children. 1- Wet hands with clean running water and apply soap. 2- Lather your hands. 3- Scrub hands for at least 20 seconds. 4- Rinse hands well under clean, running water. 5- Dry hands using a clean towel or air dry them. #FCPSSafeTogether

post_text: Keeping our school communities healthy and safe this year will require everyone doing their part. Students and staff are required to complete a daily symptom check before leaving home for school each morning. Students or staff exhibiting any signs of illness should not go to school. Some symptoms to look out for include a temperature of 100.4 degrees or higher; a sore throat, cough, chills, or shortness of breath that cannot be attributed to another health condition; and gastrointestinal issues such as diarrhea or indigestion. Students and staff exhibiting any of these symptoms are to stay home. #FCPSSafeTogether

To earn the recognition, at least 75 percent of the schools in the school division had to become Common Sense Certified Schools. Certification is earned by preparing students to think critically and use technology responsibly, while preparing them for the dangers that exist in the online realm, such as plagiarism, loss of privacy and cyberbullying. Fewer than 150 school districts in the United States have been recognized as a Common Sense District.

post_text: As part of our celebration of Black History Month, we share the following- Frederick County Junior High School (the former Frederick County Middle School on Linden Drive) was Frederick County’s first fully integrated public school. In 1965, Julian Evoid Brown, Jr., became the first black student to graduate from James Wood High School.

post_text: As part of our celebration of Black History Month, we share the following- Presbyterians in Winchester constructed the Old Stone Church around 1788. In 1858, the building was leased to the Old School Congregation Baptist Church of Color for $500. In 1878, Winchester’s first public school for black children, the Winchester Colored School, opened in the building. By the 1920’s, the building was no longer large enough to house all of the students enrolled at the school so the city decided to construct the Douglas School which opened in 1927. Black students from Woodstock to Winchester who wanted to pursue an education beyond the eighth grade attended the Douglas School. The school closed in 1966 after the integration of Winchester and Frederick County Public Schools.

post_text: Pursuant to Virginia Code Section 57-38.1, the Frederick County School Board hereby gives notice of the discovery of 10 unknown and abandoned gravesites located at 471 White Oak Road in Stephens City, Virginia. Aylor Middle School and are believed to have been part of the Reed family cemetery. A public hearing regarding how to appropriately honor and memorialize those buried on the site will be held during the Frederick County School Board meeting on December 17, 2019, at 7 p.m. The meeting will be held in the James Wood Middle School Library located at 1313 Amherst St., Winchester, Virginia. Questions or any information which may assist in efforts to identify the persons buried on the site may be directed to Frederick County Public Schools Coordinator of Planning and Development Wayne Lee at leew@frederick.k12.va.us or 540-662-3888 x88249.
